definition.primary: The small saphenous vein (SSV), formerly called the short or lesser saphenous vein, is a superficial vein of the posterior calf that courses from the lateral malleolus to the popliteal fossa, typically draining into the popliteal vein at the saphenopopliteal junction.
key_concepts: Located in posterior compartment of lower leg
Common source of incompetence causing lateral/posterior leg varicosities

origin.formation: Continuation of lateral marginal vein of foot
origin.location: Behind lateral malleolus, lateral aspect of Achilles tendon

course.lower_leg: Ascends posterior calf between gastrocnemius heads
course.fascial_relationship: Initially subfascial, then pierces fascia at variable level to run in saphenous compartment
course.midline_course: Generally follows midline of posterior calf

variations.description: Continues as Giacomini vein to join GSV or posterior thigh veins
Branches to both popliteal and thigh extension

fascial_compartment.saphenous_compartment: Potential space between muscular fascia and saphenous fascia

anatomy.formation: Union of medial sural cutaneous (tibial n.) and lateral sural cutaneous (common peroneal n.)
anatomy.course: Descends with SSV in saphenous compartment

clinical_significance: Risk of injury during stripping, ablation, or surgery
Paresthesia/numbness of lateral foot most common complication of SSV intervention
More closely applied to SSV in lower calf

distance_from_ssv.popliteal_fossa: More distant but still at risk

major_perforators.name: Soleal perforators
major_perforators.significance: May need treatment in SSV reflux

intersaphenous_communications.name: Giacomini vein
intersaphenous_communications.course: Posterior thigh, connects SSV to GSV
intersaphenous_communications.significance: May be source of GSV reflux if SSV incompetent

valves.location: More valves in distal SSV, fewer proximally
valves.saphenopopliteal_valve: Terminal valve at SPJ, key competence point

associated_varicosities: Can contribute to medial varicosities via Giacomini

standard_views.position: Prone or standing, knee slightly flexed
standard_views.assessment: Reflux with Valsalva or calf compression/release

standard_views.critical: Mark SPJ level and any thigh extension before intervention

reflux_criteria.abnormal: > 0.5 seconds reflux (some use > 1 second for SSV)
reflux_criteria.measurement: During Valsalva or after calf squeeze release

anatomic_variations_to_document: Level of SPJ (cm from popliteal crease)
Relationship to sural nerve if visible

treatment_options.considerations: Tumescent protects sural nerve, treat to SPJ
Similar to EVLA, may have slightly lower nerve injury rate
Less invasive, may have higher recurrence
Rarely performed now, higher nerve injury risk

sural_nerve_protection: Avoid treating below mid-calf with thermal ablation

learning_objectives: Describe the anatomic course of the small saphenous vein
Identify common anatomic variations of the SPJ
Understand the relationship of SSV to sural nerve
Recognize patterns of SSV reflux and associated varicosities
Apply anatomic knowledge to intervention planning
key_points: SSV runs in posterior calf from lateral malleolus to popliteal fossa
SPJ anatomy is highly variable - must map before intervention
Giacomini vein connects SSV to GSV in 20-30% of patients
Sural nerve injury is main complication risk with SSV treatment
Always mark SPJ level with ultrasound before ablation
clinical_pearls: Always scan the entire SSV including thigh extension before treating
SSV reflux can cause medial varicosities via Giacomini vein
Stop thermal ablation at mid-calf or use sclerotherapy distally
High SPJ recurrence rate if junction not adequately treated
